\section{Another Proof of Darboux's Theorem}

\begin{proof}

We assume that $ f^{\prime}(a) < \lambda < f^{\prime}(b)$, and consider a function $F\colon[a,b]\rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ defined by $F(x) = f(x) - \lambda x$.
Then $F^{\prime}(x) = f^{\prime}(x) - \lambda$, and find that $F^{\prime}(a) = f^{\prime}(a) - \lambda <0$ and $F^{\prime}(b)= f^{\prime}(b)-\lambda >0$.
This means that the function $F$ is not monotonic on $[a,b]$ in the sense that there exist $x, y, z\in [a,b]$ such that $x < y < z$ satisfying  exactly one and only one of the following conditions $(a)$ or $(b)$.

\begin{enumerate}[(a)]
\item $F(x) < F(y)$ and $F(y) > F(z)$ We prove the theorem for this case.
\item $F(x) > F(y)$ and $F(y) < F(z)$. Proof in this case follows by a similar argument.
\end{enumerate}

\begin{enumerate}[(i)]
\item  $F(x) < F(z)$
\item $F(z) < F(x)$
\item $F(z) = F(x)$.
